org.orgName: The United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington

div1.p: 1078 IN RE: PETITION of JAMES P. LAVIN & SISTER M. ANGELIQUE of the HOUSE of the GOOD SHEPARD for WRIT of CERTORIARI
1078 IN RE: PETITION of JAMES P. LAVIN & SISTER M. ANGELIQUE of the HOUSE of the GOOD SHEPARD for WRIT of CERTORIARI
Reproduced at the National Archives at Seattle
(Action to Remove a Habeas Corpus Case to US Circuit Court)
IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Petition of James P. Lavin, Immigrant Inspector and Sister M. Angelique, Sister Superior of the House of the Good Shepherd, for a Writ of Certiorari}
No. Petition.
To the Hon. Cornelius H. Hanford, Judge of the above entitled Court for the District of Washington-:
Comes now James P. Levin and Sister M. Angelique, by Edward E. Cushman, Assistant United States Attorney, and respectfully shows the Court:
I.

That prior to the commencement of the suit hereinafter mentioned, the said James P. Lavin was, and still is an revenue officer in the Treasury Department, to-wit, an Immigrant Inspector, for the District of Puget Sound Collection District; that heretofore,in the discharge of his duties as such officer, on the 9th day of Febuary, 1903, he temporarily removed from the "Rosalis" a steam ship, upon its arrival in Seattle, from the foreign port of Victoria, Yvonne Le Fevre, Marie Le Fevre and Georgette Normand, for the purpose of determining and investigating whether they were immigrants properly entitled to enter the United States; that thereafter, a Board of Inquiry was convened of the Treasury officials and Revenue officers according to law and the regulations of the Treasury Department, to investigate and determine the eligibility of the above named immigrants to land and enter the United States that upon such investigation, it was found and determined that said immigrants had within one year prior thereto been imported into the United States, at the port of New York, from France, for purposes of prostitution. It was further found and determined that each one of them was liable to become a public charge. It was further found that they had

immediatly prior to being taken from said vessel for such purpose by your petitioner, left the United States and gone to Victoria, from which place they were returning to the United States; that upon this state of facts it was found and determined that they were not lawfully entitled to be in or enter the United States, and that they should be deported and returned to the country from whence they came; that said matter was held under advisement by the Tresury Department and said officers, pending a determination and order as to whether they should be deported to Victoria in the Province of Canada or the Republic of France, and that pending such determination your petitioner, James P. Lavin, as such officer, was and still is detaining and restraining of liberty each of said immigrants above named By express warrant & direction of the Secretary of the Treasury and as they are women, said petitioner has delegated the office of their detention and restraint to your petitioner Sister M. Angelique, and that she has been and iss so restraining them of their liberty, acting under and by authority of the your petitioner, James P. Lavin. That heretofore, to-wit, on the 13th day of February, 1903, in the Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of King, an action and suit is was commenced on the part of saidx immigrants, Yvonne Le Fevre, Marie Le Fevre and Georgette Normand, against your petitioner, Sister M. Angelique, so acting as aforesaid, under color of her aforesaid office, by authority of the laws of the United States and the regulations of the Treasury Department and and direction ofyour petitioner James P. Lavin.That your petitioner, Sister M. Angelique, has been served with process, to-wit, a writ of habeas corpus, in said suit, entitled, "In the Matter of the Application of Yvonne Le Fefre, Mari Le Fevre and Georgette Normad," and being numbered 38028 in said Court; that there has not been as yet any trial or final hearing of said suit. Your petitioners therefore pray that in persuance of the laws of the United States that the said suit so commenced in the said Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of King may be removed therefrom

into this Honorable Court for trial, and thereupon proceed as a cause originally commenced in the same, and that a writ of certiorari in this behalf issue from this Honorable Court to the said Superior Court of the State of Washington for the Couty of King.
Edward E Cushman Assistant United States Attorney
United Statesof America District of Washington} SS.
James P. Lavin, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is the petitioner above named, and the matters hereinabove set forth in said petition are true in substance and in fact.
James P. Lavin
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 13 day of February, 1903.
C.H. Hanford U.S. District Judge

I, Edward E. Cushman, Assistant United States Attorney, hereby certify that as a counsel for the petitioners I have examined the proceedings against petitioners mentioned in the foregoing petition, now pending in the State Court therin mentioned, and carefully inquired into all matters set forth in the said petiion, and belive them to be true.
Edward E Cushman Assistant United States Attorney
Due and full service of within acknowledge this day of, 189 Attorney for
TX
FORM NO.499 NO.1078
IN THE Circuit COURT OF THE UNITES STATES FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON Northern Division.
THE UNITED STATES VS. In re petition of Lavin et al for Certiorari
Petition
FILED IN THE U.S. Circuit Court DIST. OF WASHINGTON FEB 14 1908 A.REEVES AYRES, Clerk HM WALTHEW Dep.
WILSON R. GAY, UNITED STATES ATTORNEY, SEATTLE, WASHINGTON
